etymologies: mid 17th century: from the phrase hand in cap; originally a pastime in which one person claimed an article belonging to another and offered something in exchange, any difference in value being decided by an umpire. All three deposited forfeit money in a cap; the two opponents showed their agreement or disagreement with the valuation by bringing out their hands either full or empty. If both were the same, the umpire took the forfeit money; if not it went to the person who accepted the valuation. The term handicap race was applied (late 18th century) to a horse race in which an umpire decided the weight to be carried by each horse, the owners showing acceptance or dissent in a similar way: hence in the late 19th century handicap came to mean the extra weight given to the superior horse

definitions: a circumstance that makes progress or success difficult

examples.text: a criminal conviction is a handicap and a label that may stick forever

definitions: a condition that markedly restricts a person's ability to function physically, mentally, or socially

examples.text: he was born with a significant visual handicap

shortDefinitions: condition restricting person's ability to function

definitions: a disadvantage imposed on a superior competitor in sports such as golf, horse racing, and competitive sailing in order to make the chances more equal.
a race or contest in which a disadvantage is imposed on a superior competitor

examples.text: the trophy for the $75,000 Ak-Sar-Ben Handicap

shortDefinitions: contest in which handicap is imposed

definitions: the extra weight to be carried in a race by a racehorse on the basis of its previous performance to make its chances of winning the same as those of the other horses.
shortDefinitions: extra weight carried in race by racehorse

definitions: the number of strokes by which a golfer normally exceeds par for a course (used as a method of enabling players of unequal ability to compete with each other)

examples.text: his game struggles along in the 20-handicap range

shortDefinitions: number of strokes by which golfer exceeds par

examples.text: lack of funding has handicapped the development of research
without a good set of notes you will handicap yourself when it comes to exams
